text: The voiced alveolar, dental and postalveolar plosives (or stops) are types of consonantal sounds used in many spoken languages. The symbol in the International Phonetic Alphabet that represents voiced dental, alveolar, and postalveolar plosives is (although the symbol can be used to distinguish the dental plosive, and the postalveolar), and the equivalent X-SAMPA symbol is `d`. ==Features== Features of the voiced alveolar stop: * There are three specific variants of : ** Dental, which means it is articulated with either the tip or the blade of the tongue at the upper teeth, termed respectively apical and laminal. ** Denti-alveolar, which means it is articulated with the blade of the tongue at the alveolar ridge, and the tip of the tongue behind upper teeth. ** Alveolar, which means it is articulated with either the tip or the blade of the tongue at the alveolar ridge, termed respectively apical and laminal. ==Occurrence== ===Dental or denti-alveolar=== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2"|Language !! Word !! IPA!! Meaning !! Notes |- | rowspan="2" | Armenian || Eastern || / demk’ || ||'face' || Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | Western|| / dal || ||'to give' || Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | colspan="2" | Bashkir || / dürt || || 'four' || |- | colspan="2" | Basque || || || 'money' || Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | colspan="2" | Belarusian || /padarožža || || 'travel' || Laminal denti-alveolar. See Belarusian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Bengali || দুধ/ |||| 'milk'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. Contrasts aspirated and unaspirated forms. See Bengali phonology |- | colspan="2" | Catalan || || || 'finger' || Laminal denti-alveolar. See Catalan phonology |- | Chinese || Wu || 唐/da || || 'the Tang dynasty' || |- | colspan="2" | Dinka || || || 'distinct' || Laminal denti-alveolar. Contrasts with alveolar . |- | Dutch || Belgian || || || 'thing' || Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | rowspan="4" | English || Dublin || rowspan="3" | then || rowspan="3" | || rowspan="3" | 'then' || rowspan="2" | Laminal denti-alveolar. Corresponds to in other dialects; in Dublin it may be instead. See English phonology |- | Southern Irish |- | Geordie || Word-initial allophone of ; may be realized as instead. |- | Ulster || dream || || 'dream' || Laminal denti-alveolar. Allophone of before , in free variation with an alveolar stop. |- | colspan="2" | Esperanto || || || 'world' || See Esperanto phonology |- | colspan="2" | French || || || 'canopy'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. See French phonology |- | colspan="2" | Georgian || || ||'tail'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. See Georgian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Hindustani || / /|| || 'milk' || Laminal denti-alveolar. See Marathi phonology |- | colspan="2" | Nepali ||/|||| 'daytime'|| Contrasts with aspirated form. See Nepali Phonology |- | colspan="2" | Pashto || /dwa |||| 'two'|| Laminal denti- alveolar. |- | colspan="2" | Polish || || || 'home'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. See Polish phonology |- | Portuguese || Many dialects || || || 'to give'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. May palatalize or lenite in certain environments, depending on dialect. See Serbo-Croatian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Slovene || || || 'today' || Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | colspan="2" | Spanish || || || 'sunken'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. See Spanish phonology |- | colspan="2" | Turkish || || || 'twig'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. See Turkish phonology |- | colspan="2" | Ukrainian || /derevo || || 'tree' || Laminal denti-alveolar. See Ukrainian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Uzbek || | sifatida || [siɸætidæ]|| 'as'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. |- | Zapotec|| Tilquiapan || dan || || 'countryside'|| Laminal denti-alveolar. |} ===Alveolar=== {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2"|Language !! Word !! IPA!! Meaning !! Word !! IPA!! Meaning !! Notes |- | colspan="2" | Arabic || /diin || || 'religion' || Laminal denti-alveolar or alveolar, depending on the dialect. See Arabic phonology. |- | rowspan="3" | English || Broad South African || rowspan="3" | dawn || || rowspan="3" | 'dawn' || rowspan="3" | Laminal denti- alveolar for some speakers, alveolar for other speakers. |- | Scottish || |- | Welsh || |- | German || Standard || || || 'or' || Varies between laminal denti-alveolar, laminal alveolar and apical alveolar. See Standard German phonology |- | Norwegian || Urban East || || || 'dance' || Partially voiced or fully voiceless . Varies between laminal denti-alveolar and laminal alveolar. See Norwegian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Persian || /edāre || || 'office' || Varies between laminal denti-alveolar and apical alveolar. See Persian phonology |- | colspan="2" | Slovak || || || 'into' || Varies between laminal denti-alveolar and laminal alveolar. See Slovak phonology |- | Swedish || Central Standard || || || 'day' || Varies between laminal denti-alveolar and alveolar, with the former being predominant. May be an approximant in casual speech. title: Voiced dental and alveolar plosives
